Award.AwardTitle: Evolution of resistance to pain-inducing neurotoxins: the bark scorpion-grasshopper mouse system.
Award.AbstractNarration:
Understanding the molecular changes by which organisms adapt to their environments is a central theme of evolutionary biology. With the pace of environmental change quickening due to loss of habitat worldwide and accelerated global climate change, and the exposure of humans to previously unencountered pathogens (such as HIV), the processes of molecular evolution are key to our survival and the survival of many organisms on this planet.

This project will study the evolution of resistance to scorpion venom, in ion channels, of desert-dwelling grasshopper mice. Grasshopper mice prey on scorpions and, when stung, show no adverse effects to scorpion venoms that cause intense pain and/or kill other mammals their size. This proposal will focus on the molecular evolution of a sodium ion-channel gene that is expressed in pain-sensing neurons. Species and individual differences in pain sensitivity of grasshopper mice to scorpion venom will be studied on the genetic, physiological and molecular levels, and the consequences of these differences for the behavior and ecology of these unique mice will be determined. This project will also gain further understanding of how the nervous system processes painful stimuli.

This project represents a partnership between the University of Texas, a major research university, and Sam Houston State University, a non-PhD granting institution with many students from underrepresented groups. We will recruit undergraduates from both institutions, focusing on underrepresented minorities. Additionally, this project will produce a videotape on co-evolution with the bark scorpion-grasshopper mouse system as an example of how animals make a living in the harsh desert environment. The videotape will be featured in an exhibit at the Texas Memorial Museum. Finally, our previous work on this system has already attracted interest from the media and there are plans for it to be highlighted in a National Geographic television special.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes: Intellectual Merit

This project investigated the molecular and physiological mechanisms of resistance to scorpion pain-inducing neurotoxins in the pain-pathway of desert-dwelling mice. Southern grasshopper mice (Onychomys torridus) prey on Arizona (AZ) bark scorpions (Centruroides sculpturatus) in the Sonoran desert. C. sculpturatus are intensely painful and highly toxic to small mammals. Mearns’ grasshopper mice (O. arenicola) prey on New Mexico (NM) striped bark scorpions (C. vittatus) in the Chihuahuan desert. C. vittatus are moderately painful and toxic to small mammals. While grasshopper mice are stung by bark scorpions during predatory attacks, the mice show no adverse effects to venoms that cause intense pain and kill similar-sized mammals. Project personnel collected grasshopper mice from Arizona and New Mexico and compared their pain-pathway neurons to the neurons of house mice that are sensitive to the venom. The results of the study showed that bark scorpion venom causes pain in sensitive animals, like house mice and humans, by activating the proteins (ion channels) in their pain-pathway that transmit pain signals to the brain. Grasshopper mice are resistant to venom-induced pain because their pain-pathway ion channels bind the venom and block the transmission of pain signals to the brain. The study also showed that bark scorpion venom acts like an analgesic to grasshopper mice, making them less sensitive to subsequent painful stimuli. The results of this study are significant because they increased our knowledge of the molecular and physiological mechanisms of pain signaling, and they highlighted the potential for a particular pain-pathway ion channel (Nav1.8) to serve as a target for new pain treatments that are non-addictive.

Project Outcomes: Broader Impacts

This project provided research-training opportunities to several graduate and undergraduate students. In addition to traveling to study sites in Arizona and New Mexico to help collect bark scorpions and grasshopper mice, students gained valuable hands-on experience designing and conducting behavioral experiments. Students also gained laboratory experience by cloning and sequencing the genes that encode pain-pathway ion channels from grasshopper mice, and preparing the channels for physiological analyses. All of the students that participated in this project have presented their results at either research conferences or university meetings. Many of the students participated in outreach activities by giving public talks in Arizona and New Mexico, or by leading public “after-dark scorpion hunts” in New Mexico. Finally, the bark scorpion-grasshopper mouse system was the subject for a STEM teaching tool, “A Tail of Two Scorpions”, [http://datanuggets.org/2015/08/a-tail-of-two-scorpions/]. Data Nuggets are an innovative approach for improving middle and high school students’ science and math skills. This Data Nugget is available to educators through the Michigan State University K-12 Initiative website.
